item.title: Browser finding Script
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Put that all in one line and use the ternary operator rofl.

But I really don’t think browser detection other than conditional comments for IE should be used. It’s not entirely useful, and people who browser under the Googlebot user agent will have the site completely fucked.

Read full topic

item.title: Browser finding Script
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Sync, post:1, topic:171923”][php]<?php
if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Netscape’) )//This will detect if the User is using Netscape
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Netscape (Netscape)’;//This is what will be said if you’re using Netscape, to change the text size use <h#></h#> tags
}
else if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Safari’) )
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Safari (Safari)’;
}
else if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Firefox’) )
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Mozilla Firefox (Firefox)’;
}
else if(strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Mozilla’))
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Mozilla (Gecko/Mozilla)’;
}

else if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘MSIE’) )
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Internet Explorer (MSIE)’;
}
else if(strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Opera’)) {
$browser = ‘Your browser is: opera’;
}
}
else
{
$browser = ‘You’re using an unknown browser’;//I had to do this as I couldn’t find a way of detecting Opera
}

echo $browser;//Echo is what inputs the text, $browser will input the text from the detected browser
?>[/php][/quote]
i’d do it like this, because any other browser would get labeled as opera, and there was some redundant stuff

Read full topic

item.title: Browser finding Script
item.dc:creator: @Sync Sync
item.description:
@Sync wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:5, topic:171923”]Sync, one small problem is that Opera will get labeled as Other browsers now, because it first checks for the HTTP_USER_AGENT, and since opera is put under the MSIE block, it will not find it, because opera’s user-agent doesnt show MSIE[/quote]I’ll use “Other” as a replacement for it, and I didn’t realise IE wasn’t working, fixed that.

Sync, one small problem is that Opera will get labeled as Other browsers now, because it first checks for the HTTP_USER_AGENT, and since opera is put under the MSIE block, it will not find it, because opera’s user-agent doesnt show MSIE

item.title: Browser finding Script
item.dc:creator: @Sync Sync
item.description:
@Sync wrote:

This is my first PHP tutorial, I’ve been learning HTML and PHP for the last couple of months.
This will find the browser that you’re using and Print it out, it won’t Print out useless crap like most other scripts do.
If you would like a example of the Script go here, http://syncnetwork.no-ip.org/ip,

[php]<?php
if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Gecko’) )
{
if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Netscape’) )//This will detect if the User is using Netscape
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Netscape (Netscape)’;//This is what will be said if you’re using Netscape, to change the text size use <h#></h#> tags
}
if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Safari’) )
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Safari (Safari)’;
}
else if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘Firefox’) )
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Mozilla Firefox (Firefox)’;
}
else
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Mozilla (Gecko/Mozilla)’;
}
if(ereg(‘Opera(/| )([0-9].[0-9]{1,2})’, $HTTP_USER_AGENT, $log_version))
{
$browser = ‘Opera’;
}
}
else if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘MSIE’) )
{
if ( strpos($_SERVER[‘HTTP_USER_AGENT’], ‘MSIE’) )
{
$browser = ‘Your Browser is: Internet Explorer (MSIE)’;
}
}
else
{
$browser = ‘Other’;//If your browser isn’t detected it will input this.
}

echo $browser;//Echo is what inputs the text, $browser will input the text from the detected browser
?>[/php]

I almost used $ in the <?php tag lol :D.

Read full topic
